Cuerpo:
JUNO justifiably created a buzz at the Oscars. For here's a film that tackles a tangled topic -- teen pregnancy -- without getting into knots and tangles. It's such a fresh, uncomplicated look at one of the most compelling problems today. And it becomes more important in countries like India where an iron curtain is doggedly pulled down on such occurrences, despite the fact that teen sex -- and pregnancy -- is a truth that should no longer be denied here.

movie

LAST year, they gave us Epic Movie, a film that spoofed almost all the recent Hollywood films. This year, the target is Frank Miller's successful gorefest 300, where King Leonidas goes to war against the mean Mr Xerxes with his spartan (just a handful) army of Spartans, while his queen (Carmen Electra) waits for her warrior to return, with a bit of fun and frolic to bide her time.

Of course, it's all supposed to be intensely funny, with Xerxes being fat and gross and Leonidas being born with a beard and six packs and being trained the Daniel Craig-Casino Royale way (he's hardened by being hit where it hurts the most). But the slapstick jokes are so loud, so grotesque (mostly to do with vomit, fecus), they fail to tickle your funny bone. Also, the film chooses to spoof any and everything that has been entertainment news including a bald Britney, Brangelina's adoption bid, Paris Hilton and her pet dog, the judges on American Idol....too crowded, clumsy and kitchy.

SOUTH Korea has been trying to do a Hollywood for long. This time, it comes a bit close, specially in terms of special effects. Prolonged shots a giant monster slithering across the landscape of Los Angeles, guzzling cars, buildings and humans isn't quite Jurassic Park, Godzilla or King Kong. Nevertheless, it isn't tacky at all and does manage to make you slide back in your seats a bit to avoid the snaky-tongued serpent lunging across the screen.

It's an ancient Korean myth reworked by the film maker who brings to life a pair of lovers 500 years after they committed suicide in order to escape the fury of an imoogi (a bad serpent) who wanted to metamorphose into a dragon. And the only way he could do it was by gulping the girl with the dragon tattoo. Now, she happens to be in L.A. with the tattoo intact and the imoogi knows it must slither across the seas and hiss on American soil, in order to fulfil its serpentine fantasies. But remember, the girl has the guy to save her -- again the ancient lover, reborn as a newspaper reporter. And it takes more than mere pen-pushing to out-fang the enemy.

The film blends the occidental and the oriental as it moves between America, here and now, and Korea's Chosun dynasty, 500 years ago. More importantly, it showcases South Korea's advances in film technology in this lavishly mounted film that has a feel -- just a feel -- of Hollywood.

TWO terminally ill patients discover a rare bond of friendship in the clinical environs of a hospital room and draw up a `bucket list' of things they'd like to do, before they hit the bucket. Ordinary. But if the dying duo includes Jack Nicholson and Morgan Freeman, the ordinary story gets a dash of extraordinary. Specially when the two are poles apart and are called upon to play characters they are adept at essaying.

Jack Nicholson is Jack Nicholson: the irascible, mean, impolite millionaire who has made his millions, but has no one to share the bounty with. He's failed miserably in all his relationships, despite being married four times and having a daughter who hasn't seen him for years. The only person he can communicate with is his secretary, but he makes it a point to be offensive with him too. Morgan meanwhile, is so very Morgan: the gentle giant who may not have the millions, having spent his life under cars as a mechanic; yet he has family, family values and faith. Despite their class differences, the two cancer patients find a camaraderie that sees them sharing some of the most memorable moments of their lives together, even as they attend to all the unfinished business before signing off. So you have them sky diving, Himalaya climbing, Taj wowing, Pyramid gazing....and giving each other the lessons in life that still remain unlearnt.

A sweet, feel good film about death and friendship, The Bucket List is more about kalakars (actors) than kahani (story).

You need to make a choice: who's the fairest of them all. Is it Tom (Zach Braff) the laggard who needs to work (in an advertising agency) because his lawyer wife's had a baby, but hates his job, hates his boss and doesn't have much to boast about. Or is it Chip (Jason Bateman), the wheel chaired boss who hates Tom and loves his wife (Amanda Peet) who happens to be his high-school flame.

Tom and Chip play a vile game of upmanship, with each trying to outdo the other at being mean. Of course, Chip has the veneer of niceness around him, which makes him win all the sympathy, while Tom is seen as the guy who can stoop so low as to throw a handicapped man off his wheelchair and even flaunt his mountain bike in his face.

There's nothing smart about this two-boys-one-girl romance which sorely lacks a comedy track, despite being mounted as a comedy

IT'S sweet, it's shmaltzy, and it's completely endearing. Primarily because the story comes straight from the heart, dealing with the attempts of a young orphan to find his parents he's never seen, with the only weapon he has: the musical compass within. Like our very own Ishaan Awasthi, August Rush is a special kid, gifted with a prodigious musical talent, and equally lonely. And it is this internal rhythm -- the music that he hears within -- that tells him he will one day find his parents, who are musicians too. He lands up in New York and finds a greedy guardian in Wizard (Robin Williams), a Fagin-like character who discovers the child's gifts and tries to use him to make a quick buck. But August isn't an ordinary kid and follows his own drums...which lead him to Central Park, where he manages to magically connect with his parents, who had also been enstranged after a clandestine encounter.

Truly dreamy, with loads of great music and stunning visuals, this is predictable, yet watchable fare. More importantly, it's Charles Dickens, revisited, albeit as a musical.

THIS classic brother versus brother film was premiered at Cannes and managed to create an impression. Maybe because its simple storyline upholds the most rudimentary lessons on moral science. As the top cop (Robert Duvall) tells his gangster son, Bobby (Joaquin Phoenix): it's a war out there, you're either with us or with the bad guys. Reminiscent of Bushspeak, did you say?

Well, here the terrorists have been supplanted by the Russian drug mafia which has spread its tentacles through New York city, with the power of muscle and gun. Bobby works for them and runs their nefarious clubs, spending most of his time in the smoky backrooms with his luscious girlfriend (Eva Mendes). Naturally, he's the black sheep of the family, since his dad's the police chief and his brother (Mark Whalberg) is a top-ranking officer, hellbent on busting the drug cartels. But all black sheep must return to the fold someday and so does this prodigal son too, specially when the drug mafia guns for his father and his brother. First he doubles up as an informer, while working within the mob, but when his cover is blown and violence strikes, he joins the force itself and literally smokes 'em out.

Actually, with such high-performers like Joaquin, Wahlberg and Duvall, the film could have been a cracker. But the predictable script and the formulaic twists and turns reduce it to a run-of-the-mill, albeit watchable film. The biggest casualty is Eva Mendes who is completely wasted in the all-boys bandobast.

Hollywood would like to peddle this film as a sequel to The Devil Wears Prada, that sweet and edgy ode to the Bi***y Boss-badgered employee relationship. But this one's simply sweet and hardly edgy. And that's because there's no Meryl Streep to play the acerbic angel in Devil's clothing. Nevertheless there's a Julia Robertish (read My Best Friend's Wedding) feel which transforms this routine romance into fairy tale fluff.

Jane Nichols (Katherine Heigl) is the archetypal good samaritan who has spent her short life doing stuff for people as their Best Buddy, Best Secretary, Best Big Sister, Best Elder Daughter....And Best Bridesmaids too. With 27 bridesmaid's dresses stuffed in her closet, she doesn't seem to have space for any more. Specially not in this case, where she'd rather be the bride than the bridesmaid. For her younger sister Tess arrives in New York, indulges in a whirlwind romance with the man she has silently adored -- her boss -- and decides to marry him, while Jane watches, heartbroken and horribly distressed. Add to this the vexatious journo (James Marsden) who writes about her pitiable `Always, always the Bridesmaid' status in his column, and you have sweet Jane subsumed by a tsunami of woes. Somewhere down the demanding line, Jane must suspend her sweetness and learn to say `No', if she wants to graduate from bridesmaid to bride and de-clutter her closet by discarding the 27 dresses for that one dream dress in white.

Both Heigl and Marsden put up a spirited show as the quibbling couple, with the film throwing up some comic sequences as an overworked Jane keeps hopping from an American wedding to an Indian wedding and ends up wearing the bindi on a dress. Nope, it's not easy being a bridesmaid, specially when there's so much love in the air.

PRE-HISTORY pre-supposes loads and loads of super special effects and high octane action with quixotic characters that are bullish, bearish, bindaas folks who have more to distinguish them from their modern cousins than their animal skin underwear. Does Roland Emmerich's blast from the past pass this litmus test and give you the mandatory masala? Only partially.

movie

COYBOW Clint is fast emerging as one of the most serious directors of Hollywood. Ever since Unforgiven, the actor-director has proved his forte with meaningful cinema that makes America and the world sit up. Letters...is a sequel to his earlier film Flags of Our Fathers, where the director approaches the same events of World War ll from the other side. If the first film showcased the heroics of the American soldiers who fought a fierce battle in the island of Iwo Jima against the Japanese, then the second film lays down the anguish and the heroism of the Japanese soldiers, who were fighting a losing battle under expedient conditions. A terrific idea and a truly global perspective which smartly brings to light the futility of war.

The film is entirely in Japanese, with subtitles, and the Americans are shown either in flashback or as a prisoner of war who is treated with utmost warmth by his enemies. Even Ken Watanbe as General Kuribayashi, who heads the Japanese regiment, is actually a humane pacifist who sorrowfully watches his soldiers die and reminisces of his earlier amiable encounters with the Americans, when he believed Americans and Japs were natural allies rather than enemies. There are moving sequences of battle, specially those where the young Japanese boys prefer to kill themselves with grenades when their own army abandons them.

In the end, Letters... is a moving -- and artistic -- indictment of war and violence which should actually have no place in global politics.

RASHOMON, did anyone say? Oh puhlease! let's leave the classics alone. 'Coz Hollywood is perfect as pulp fiction and there's nothing wrong with that.

The American President goes to Spain to attend an anti-terror conference and ends up a victim of a terror plot himself. The busy-body intelligence agencies sniff the plot and send a double to take the bullet as he steps forward to address the restless crowd. But it's the US intelligence, remember and they rarely get their statistics right when it comes to weapons of destruction. Hence, even as the POTUS thinks he's safe, coccooned in a high-security hotel, masked intruders kidnap him at gunpoint, bundle him in an ambulance and head for an undisclosed destination, through the crowded streets of the bustling town. Hey, but didn't these Morrocan terrorists do their homework on the fearlessness of the American cop who can save the Prez, even if bullets fly, bombs explode and the cityscape crumbles...

This time, it's Dennis Quaid who plays dare-devil cop, but that's just one part of story. The more interesting parts are the eight versions of the assassination attempt, as the event is told -- and re-told -- through the eyes of the different people who were present there. You can even view the hungama through the eyes of a pretty little girl who loses her mama in the melee, when all she wanted to do was to enjoy an ice-cream.

Interesting. But just one query: what was Sigourney Weaver doing in a split-second scene?

HANNIBAL Cannibal sit back, Sweeney Todd and his piping hot meat pie missus are here. And they do the human morsel munching, better, bolder and bloodier than Anthony Hopkins cheek-chewing act in The Silence of The Lambs.

At the outset, it would be only fair to warn the viewer that there is nothing, simply nothing, uplifting nor enlightening in this bleak black comedy about one man's revenge against a world that robbed him of his wife and child. Ethically, the film is an extreme low-life experience as it plots the moral degradation of a man who has gone mad with his anguish and lust for revenge. Adaptated from Broadway's bloodiest musical, Tim Burton's celluloid adaptation is both bleak and brilliant, despite sending out all the wrong messages and serenading the cult of the macabre. But when was cinema meant to be a moral science lesson; and hasn't the anti-hero become more appealing than the messiah.

Hence, the importance of Sweeney Todd, the razor-sharp barber of backstreet London, who displays how rage can turn a gentle soul into a demon and sorrow can transform a sensitive soul into a soulless killing machine. And it takes the talent of Johnny Depp to create a towering character out of a cold-blooded killer who slits the throat of his customers instead of giving them a shave and sends them down through a chute to the pie shop below. Why? So that his landlady, the fiendish Mrs Lovett (Helena Bonham Carter) can mince them up for her succulent meat pies which have become the rage of impoverished and hunger-stricken London. The enigmatic duo see nothing wrong in their devilish deeds, because Mr Todd is doing it for revenge (his family has been ruined by an unscrupulous judge, Alan Rickman), and Mrs Lovett's doing it for love (she adores the anguished barber and wants him any which way.)

We recommend this extreme barbarism, only because of its artistic excellence -- London landscaped like Charles Dickens described it -- and for the fact that it depicts evil with an integrity too. There are no apologies for the unmitigated blood-letting and the tone is non-judgmental as the film descends into the very dregs of the human psyche. What's more enthralling are the performances by the lead players (Depp and Bonham Carter) who are never abhorrent, despite their vile acts. And the fact that they do their own singing in this musical only adds to the histrionic's show. Watch it, for this might be the funkiest freak show in town.

IT takes 11 and a half minutes of the film to come up with its first dialogue: `There she is!' Our protagonist Daniel Plainview (Day-Lewis) who has been assiduously digging into the bowels of the earth finds his hidden treasure: silver. That seems to set the note of this art house investigation into America's twin towers: oil and religion. It's reticent and diligent and grows on you. Although a turn-of-the-century account of a miner's growing fortunes as he taps the oil-rich Californian reserves and comes in conflict with the local godman, the film is relevant even today. Simply because America hasn't abandoned its obsession -- with oil and God -- till now.

It's an epical portrayal of a not-so-nice man who grows into the archetypal capitalist, buying up all the land without bothering about the people who inhabit it. So much so, he even loses interest in his son after the kid is injured in an accident and ends up a tortured, mangled soul, instead of the astute business partner he was grooming him to be. Plainview plainly lacks humanism and is powered only by an unlimited greed for money as he bleeds the community of Little Boston dry. He dreams big and hopes to set up a pipeline to transmit his abundant supplies of oil without sharing his profits with the shipping companies, but dreams don't always come true. Specially when there is the local godman who wants a share in the oil money to augment the power of the church. So what if he's transforming religion into drama too, with his hysterical exorcisms and healing rituals....It's a disturbing picture of America's rise to power. Because if people like Daniel Plainview powered it to superpower status, the nation doesn't really have a happy past to reflect upon. Watch it for Anderson's eye for detail and for Daniel Day-Lewis who lends grandeur a period charm to Plainview despite his questionable motives.

GEORGE Clooney has perfected the role of the tormented insider by now. Time and again, he has displayed his skills at delineating one of Hollywood's favourite characters: the insider-turned-rebel who wants to clean up the mess he has partly created. So you see him moving from cold complicity to seething anger and final rebellion, all with the characteristic Clooney charisma, almost reminiscent of what Matt Damon has done with Jason Bourne, the renegade agent on the run.

Here, he plays a `fixer' in a law firm who basically sees himself as a `janitor', since his job entails a lot of cleaning-up behind the scenes to ensure the high-powered clients win, any which way. Doesn't matter if they are guilty or not, the moneyed must always go scott-free, for what are legal eagles for. So, everything's fair in biz and war, even defending a corporation that is being rightly sued for poisonous pollution. But only until Clayton's friend and mentor (Tom Wilkinson) gets the conscience call. Time for Clayton to discover the hero within and stop sleepwalking through his monotonous life that is as drab as his power suits and his poker games.

Reminds you of Erin Brokovich? Right. The film has the same premise about guilty-as-hell gargantuan corporations that can be brought down on their knees by something as simple as a conscience break. The narrative does get somewhat dense, here and there, but leave it to Clooney to carry you through this legal maze that takes a detour into the character's personal hell -- his tangled private life -- too.

IF you loved The Devil Wears Prada, rest assured, you will like this one. Because both the films follow the same storyline. They view the lives of the She-Devils (the super-rich, supposedly insensitive, high-society miss) through the wide-eyed innocence of young, working class girls. And come up with similar conclusions: The b***hes aren't really bad; the devil wears Prada and a heart on its sleeve too!

College grad Scarlett Johansson faces her first interview question: So who are you? That's an easy one, she smiles and begins to answer it. But hey, what's this, she stammers, stutters and realises she doesn't know who she is. She walks out of the interview and sits in Central Park, wondering what comes next. Abracadabra! She saves a boisterous kid and ends up as a nanny in a swanky Manhattan house, taking time-off to discover who she really is. Isn't an easy search, specially when her employer (Laura Linney) is the perfect boss -- absolutely and irrationally demanding. And the family is a completely dysfunctional one with a husband who likes to get touch-feely with the hot nanny.

Add to this, a rich neighbour who likes to send her roses and a mother who likes to see her daughter in power suits instead of a domestic help and you have some nice dramatic tension to rev up the show. Johansson tries hard to don the plain Jane look, but can't keep the cute-cool girl away for long. Quite natty, this little nanny.

NO prizes for guessing who is a jumper. Really, it's just someone who can jump. Only this time, the jump can take you from Manhattan (or some place in the US) to the Colosseum, in just a flurry and a flash. They call it tele-kinetic transportation which sees our young hero jump away from his messed up life whenever trouble is in sight. Having discovered the genetic mutation in him as a kid, he uses his power not the Spidey way. No saving the world business for our Daniel (Hayden) who just wants to jump into banks, rob them and then whiz off to exotic locales. But he's a hero, remember. He needs to do something good atleast, like saving his high school sweetheart and himself from a gang of exterminators who have just one mission: they want to hunt down the Jumpers and kill them because they believe only God can be anywhere and everywhere at all times, not humans. A sad-looking Samuel L. Jackson heads the terminator squad and doesn't really know how to jumpstart this dead role.

Give us the real jumpers -- Spiderman, Batman, Superman or Neo (Matrix), anyday.

THIS is crazy, zany and absolutely delightful Disney fare that is determined to light up your evening with its brilliant re-writing of the quintessential fairy tale. Part feature and part animation, Enchanted airlifts Snow White aka Giselle (Amy Adams), Prince Charming aka Edward (James Marsden) and the wicked stepmom aka Queen Narissa (Susan Sarandon), armed with her poisoned apple, straight onto Times Square. And strangely, there are no air pockets in this seamless adaptation of the timeless Snow White legend into a modern-day romance, where the airy-fairy princess tries to prove that happily-ever-after isn't a pop-up bookish truth alone. It can happen even in singleton-obsessed Manhattan....

Of course, the film wouldn't be enchanting if there wasn't a twist in the tale. When the dreamy-eyed animated character Giselle meets her Prince Charming and is all set to marry him, she is pushed into a deep well by her prospective mom-in-law, only to emerge out of a man hole in Times Square, as a living breathing human. She roams around the streets of New York, waiting for her prince to rescue her and ends up with a dreamy divorce lawyer (Dempsey) who is divorced himself and has a little daughter. No prizes for guessing where the new love story begins....But before Giselle can find her true love, she must consume the poisoned apple, talk to her chipmunk friend and battle the feisty, fire brand and deliciously evil Queen, who follows her to NYC. Of course, first she tries to keep a watch on her through all kinds of magic mirrors: soup bowls, wine glasses, but then tires off and takes things in her slimy hands. Time for the film to fly off far beyond the realms of imagination....

Go, have a ball, literally.

IT'S sweet, it's shmaltzy, and it's completely endearing. Primarily because the story comes straight from the heart, dealing with the attempts of a young orphan to find his parents he's never seen, with the only weapon he has: the musical compass within. Like our very own Ishaan Awasthi, August Rush is a special kid, gifted with a prodigious musical talent, and equally lonely.

And it is this internal rhythm -- the music that he hears within -- that tells him he will one day find his parents, who are musicians too. He lands up in New York and finds a greedy guardian in Wizard (Robin Williams), a Fagin-like character who discovers the child's gifts and tries to use him to make a quick buck. But August isn't an ordinary kid and follows his own drums...which lead him to Central Park, where he manages to magically connect with his parents, who had also been enstranged after a clandestine encounter.

Truly dreamy, with loads of great music and stunning visuals, this is predictable, yet watchable fare. More importantly, it's Charles Dickens, revisited, albeit as a musical.

TWO families try to cope with tragedy, guilt and revenge in this serious drama which does have its moments. Joaquin Phoenix and wife Jennifer Connelly are returning home after wowing their young son's cello performance at a concert. They stop at a gas station and end up losing their son who is accidentally hit by Ruffalo who is rushing back to drop his own son at his ex-wife's house. Now Ruffalo should have stopped, but he simply drove off. So that, even as one family grieves over it's loss, the other is overburdened by guilt.

It's an interesting study of how people cope with sorrow and responsibility in their lives.

SURELY it takes more than McConaughey's pecs and Kate Hudson's contours to create a film. Yup, it takes Donald Sutherland's crisp comeback after a long-long gap to make you sit up in this run-of-the-mill adventure flick.

McConaughey is the treasure hunter who sets out to find the legendary Queen's Dowry treasure chests which were lost at sea in the 18th century. It's a search that sees him re-igniting his romance with his enstranged wife (Hudson) who is also a bounty-hunter and wants to find the treasure too. More importantly, the adventure sees them joining hands with the bored billionaire Nigel Honeycutt (Donald Sutherland) who has a bonding problem with his bimbo daughter Gemma (Alexis Dziena). Add to this a mobster and his henchman bumbling through the treasure trail and you have an average time-pass affair to opt for. Quite unlike Tennant's stylish romantic film, Hitch.

FUNERALS can be funny. That's a lesson we learnt from Hugh Grant and his friends in the smart Brit comedy, Four Weddings and a Funeral, some years ago. But this time, there are no laughs; just an attempt at crude humour.

Deadpan Daniel wants to have a dignified funeral for his dad, but soon realises this isn't a simple wish that can be easily fulfilled. Not when he has a bunch of relatives and friends who think normal is boring and a stranger who turns up uninvited, insisting he's a `close' friend of the deceased. End result? There's a naked man on the roof doing strange things after ingesting drugs, a moron who tries to cook up a romance in the desultory surroundings, a dwarf who ends up alive in the dead man's coffin and a harried son who thinks his father was exceptional and deserves a decent funeral.

A dour attempt at comedy, this one doesn't tickle you laugh anywhere.

TIME for Hollywood's favourite gangster, the Italian mafia, to fall back and give way for the all-American gangster: Frank Lucas, the black mobster who ruled New York in the 1970s. And like the Al Capones and the Corleones, this drug overlord is less of a criminal and more of a benevolent godfather to his people: his family in North Carolina and the black community in Harlem.

movie

A bunch of tourists decides to take a bus through the backwaters of Brazil and realise that it's all truly bush beyond America and Europe. In the outlawed world, there is death, disaster and decadence waiting at every crooked nook and corner.

Actually, this is quite a blinkered view that only reiterates touristy myths about exotic tourist haunts. After a bus accident, the bunch of white tourists ends up in a desolate house where a maut ka saudagar awaits them, scalpel in hand. “It's payback time,” Doctor Death tells the tourists and begins to slit their bodies for their organs which he wants to put into sick and dying Brazilians.

This blood and gore fest, which unfolds either in an underlit house or the dark underwaters of the Brazilian sea shore, is simply barbaric.

THERE'S a serial killer in town who, like all serial killers, loves to try his art work on young girls, before slashing them up. This time, he abducts young Aubrey Fleming (Lindsay Lohan), a pianist and a promising writer, and leaves her mother (Julia Ormond) and friends completely distraught. But hey, what's this! Aubrey returns, minus a hand and leg and insists she's not Aubrey, she has no mother, no boyfriend who loves blue roses, just a seamy job as a pole dancer and a lonely, unloved life. So who's the psychopath and what's he done?

Follow Lindsay Lohan as she takes you through dimly lit bars, bloody bath tubs, blue weapons of destruction and ingenious means of torture. Add to this a sentimental family track and you have decent time-pass cinema.

Alien vs Predator carry on their intergalactic confrontation in suburban America, and those who have been waiting for it finally get to witness facehuggers, alien hybrids, and the dreadlocked Predator wreak some homeland havoc.

movie

Want blood. See blood. And how? Vietnam war veteran John Rambo returns on a rescue mission, this time in Myanmar, and spills guts in all his former glory. If you pay close attention, you can even catch a head been blown away, a body splitting into two and a stomach being sliced to bring out the insides. All this bloodletting obviously is orchestrated by our hero who doesn't twitch a facial muscle nore register a flicker on his brow. Ekdum bindaas!

For all those who got hooked on to Rambo's exploits in First Blood, his Fourth Blood heroics may bring back nostalgic memories of a cold and clinical killing machine that killed for country, honour, justice and the rest. This time, he comes back from semi-retirement, as he did in the recent Rocky film, and joins a bunch of Americans who want to supply relief to an endangered tribe, hounded by the military junta. But that's just a pretext for our all-American hero to create an All-American film where the Myanmar natives are ruthless and mean and the bunch of white guys are heroes and vigilantes. And the white woman? Ah well, she's meant to be held captive and wail through the violence.

Forget the old-fashioned story-line. The Rambo franchise is only meant to make you dizzy about dishum-dishum. It does.

Good kidstuff. Three adorable chipmunks find refuge in a loser songwriter's house when their favourite tree is cut down. Now these aren't ordinary rodents but are real rockstars who end up turning the fortunes of down and out David. They lend their funky voices to his songs and turn them into chartbusters overnight. Soon their videos are spilling over YouTube and our new age band is selling stuff, signing autographs and going the celeb way.

End of the story? Nope. Chipmunks Inc isn't ecstatic anymore because they realise there are some things that money just can't buy. Like David's love and their dream to settle down as family with him. Like all sweet American films, this one too serenades family values as invaluable, transcending money, glamour and the glitzy glutton's life.

A bunch of girl thieves decide to rob the Federal Bank of some of the millions that have been piled up for the shredder machine, because as the gang leader Bridget (Keaton) insists, this is just recycling, not stealing. And they do it with panache, since they work there and know how to hoodwink security. Keaton's a janitor who needs the money to pay back her huge debts.

Latifah's the shredder who dreams of sending her sons to expensive private schools. And Holmes is the cart girl who wheels the old money bills while craving for a better life.

It's a coming together of three oddballs who dream the American dream and see nothing wrong in achieving it any which way.

Of course, this isn't quite the best from the big guns like Keaton and Queen Latifah nor is it hot enough for Katie Holmes. But moments of spunk suffice to carry the film through, with Keaton leading the bratpack through some heady mayhem.

Treasure hunter Ben Gates (Nicholas Cage) is back to fumbling his way through history in search of hidden truths, once again. This time, he's got to hunt down Abraham Lincoln's assassin.

Of course, we all know it was John Wilkes Booth who did it. But mysterious man Ed Harris lands up in one of Cage's lectures with a mothballed piece of parchment from Booth's diary that declares Booth's had an accomplice. And this bad guy happens to be none other than Nicholas Cage's ancestor.

Oops! Skeletons from the Gates' cupboard, huh? Time for the entire Gates family to get together and salvage the family's honour, even if it means breaking into the White House, kidnapping the President and rebuilding broken family ties. For Mama Gates (Helen Mirren) and Papa Gates (John Voight) have long been estranged, while Ben himself has a troubled relationship with girlfriend Abigail (Diane Kruger).

Loads of insipid rummaging through history's memorabilia followed by some uneventful trips to discover a forgotten city of gold don't actually make for a thrilling adventure. Surely, Oscar winner Helen Mirren must be squirming at this strange miscast, even as Nicholas Cage must have realised he desperately needs to reinvent himself for survival.

The film is supposedly an imaginary biography of noted photographer Diane Arbus who lived in New York in the 1950s. But what emerges is a highly imaginative portrait of a woman who turned her back to boring domesticity and found a new vision with her friend and neighbour, Lionel (Robert Downey Jr) who introduced her to a whole new world of marginalised, uncommon, extraordinary people. These were in stark contrast to the bored, smiling portraits which her husband photographed, while she stood by as a mere assistant and patted lipstick on the models.

The story moves along the pattern of the Beauty and the Beast fairy tale, where the buttoned-up Arbus is irresistibly drawn towards her freak neighbour who is strangely covered up in fur. But it is behind the fur that Arbus discovers a friend and soulmate who helps her transcend the binds of 1950's propriety and discover both herself and a whole new world of free birds.

The film has a slow, languorous pace which might put off many, but for those who like a different cinematic experience, Fur could end up as engaging cinema. So what if Nicole Kidman whispers through most of the film. Her eyes say it all, as does her body language.

The FBI sure does seem to have fallen on bad days. It needs to take the help of a seedy ping pong player to find out all that's wrong with ping pong. Ping pong rather than the affairs of the nation? Yeah, Christopher Walken is an erstwhile ping pong champ who never finished his training because he was a bad guy. So, now the bad guy is running a tournament where death is the penalty for losers who end up as dust jars on weirdo Walken's mantelpiece. The FBI's new mission is to bust this championship of death and the only guy who can help them is the unsuitable boy, Randy Daytona (Dan Fogler).

Now, Randy may be an ex-champ too, but he's all rusted and busted now. So before he joins the FBI as part-time help, he must spruce up is act by training under the blind master and his beautiful niece (Maggie Q) who treats ping pong like ballet. Of course there's romance round the ping pong table, but it comes in dribbles. Just like the humour which flows in half-measures as Daytona takes on his rivals and demolishes them in his characteristic clumsy manner.

Nevertheless, the film is a worthy follower of the Potter formula where a teen sets out to save the world with her magical powers. Thematically too, the film based on Philip Pullman's trilogy, His Dark Materials, has larger ethical overtones as it unleashes a debate on authority versus free will. Lyra's universe is controlled by the authoritarian Magisterium which tells people what to do, thus leaving no scope for the daemons (the free spirit that tags along each human) to express themselves.

In order to banish the daemons (read free will) completely, they have unleashed a sinister programme where they abduct all the children and programme them in human labs, so that they emerge minus the power to dissent. Quite quite in keeping with the Orwellian prophecy....But Lyra is a strong-willed girl who defies the mysterious Ms Kidman who wants to use her magical powers to master the multiple universes. Fleeing from her captor, she finds a comrade in a giant polar bear who will lead her further in her crusade. But more of that in the next sequel.

And that's the problem with Golden Compass. It's open-ended and quite unnerving, leaving the viewers a dissatisfied lot. All the special effects lead up to almost nowhere, as Lyra sails off into the horizon and promises to save the world somewhere in the future. Gawd! Who waits for Godot! As for Daniel Craig, poor Mr Bond is hardly there. Are we to rest content with two and a half scenes of this particle physicist who chases dust as his life's mission? Disconcerting, again. But watch it for its spectacle.

Six members of a book club use the novels of Jane Austen to set their own tangled love life in order. So what if they are modern metrosexuals, cosmosexual and contrasexuals guys and girls, leading post-modern lives. The retro-English artfulness that Austen patented in her man-woman relationships seems to work magic in all ages. Go find an Emma, a Darcy in this contemporary homage to Austen's sense and sensibility. A must for all Austen-philes.

If you've grown up on Nancy Drew stories, the staple fare for post-Enid Blyton, pre-Harold Robbins bookworms, you sure are gonna be disappointed by this one.

Because Nancy, the titian-haired teen detective isn't the unadulterated alpha girl you dreamt her to be. Of course, you have Emma Roberts carrying the Julia Roberts tagline (she's Julia Roberts niece) with her, but so much for that. The girl isn't a patch on her power-packed aunt. Also, the plot moves in bumps and grinds and the smart and sassy bits are downplayed.

Nancy moves to Los Angeles with her dad and the stage is set for her to unveil a long-forgotten Hollywood mystery. She tries to unravel the story behind the death of a Hollywood actress who lived in the house before her. Who killed the '80s diva Dehlia Dreycott, after she disappeared for five months: that's the intriguing question that bothers our snoopy teen as she hunts through the memorabilia in the decrepit mansion that's now home for her. Helping her out is snoopier 12-year-old Corky (Josh Flitter) who's quite smitten by our girl hero. But for us, it's still River Heights (Nancy's original playground) rather than Hollywood High and Carolyn Keene (the author of the Nancy Drew series) rather than Andrew Fleming that engage our fancy.

Based on a Stephen King short story, the film focuses on the nightmarish experience of a writer who checks into the haunted room to get inspiration for his next bestseller. The room has a horrid history, with 56 people having died in mysterious circumstances while occupying it. Also, the manager (Samuel L. Johnson) tries his best to dissuade the visitor from going on this suicidal mission.

But John insists there are no ghosts, no goblins, no vampires. Poor John! He needs a nightmare to make him see the ugly, scary truth. And if his subconscious is already traumatised by the untimely death of his young daughter, there can be no respite for him in this seedy New York Hotel room where dead bodies float, walls crack, blood drips and the radio blares with the Carpenter's single, We've Only Just Begun.

The second half gets a bit too long and repetitive and does blunt the chills of this psychological thriller. But John Cusack's lone-actor histrionics keeps you adequately engaged, as do the things that go bump and grind in the spooky room.

Sibling rivalry, anyone? Well then, there couldn't be a better case study than the War of the Claus'. Fred Claus (Vince Vaughn) spends his life fighting with his younger brother who happens to be Santa Claus (Paul Giamatti), because his mom (Kathy Bates) always wants to know why he can't be like his brother, St Nicholas.

It's a sweet and funny act from Vince Vaughn who blabbers his way through dysfunctional family business, even as he tries to prove that he is actually the best big brother in the world.

We've had talking ants and talking bugs. So what's new with talking bees in Hollywood's insectopaedia? Enough to make you sit back and laugh as you watch a stingy little fella called Barry Bee make a beeline for humankind and teach them how to bee-have.

Barry graduates from B-School and is ready to be inducted as a newbie in the honey industry. But before getting Bee-zee with the humdrum Bee-zness of life, he faces the quintessential dilemma: To Bee or not to Bee? He sets out into the human world, seeking answers and unleashes his stinger missile against humankind who have been Beekeeping all these years, without ever thinking that Bee-ing is all about freedom and all that.

He finds a willing consort in a sassy young florist who helps him wage his war over coffee and cakes. Forget the script. Go hear Renee Zellweger do a delightful voice-over and an SFX show where a zillion bees fly a plane and help it land safely, when humans fail. Truly, a buzz worthy effort.

With two action heroes for the price of one, you might have expected fireworks, specially when they are both on either side of the law.

Statham's an FBI agent who wants to avenge the murder of his partner while Li is the rogue assassin who isn't an easy catch.

Add to this, the crossfire between the Chinese underworld and the Japanese Yakuzas and you could actually be savouring the best of chopsockey. But yeh kya? Statham gets to fight Li, only in the the climax, which isn't really paisa vasool stuff.

Masala for the kiddies! Five adorable pups go on a rescue mission after their mom and dad have been dognapped. And mind you, these are no ordinary puppies; they all have distinct identities and can talk too. So you have Budderball who is always hungry, B-Dawg who likes a bit of bling-bling on his body, Bud-dha who unwinds with yoga, Mudbud whose favourite game is getting muddy and Rosebud, who wears a rose behind her ear and is the quintessential alpha girl who is balsy enough to stand up against the bad wolf, while the boys quiver.

Take the kids for a treat for this endearing sequel to Disney's Air Bud franchise. After all, dogs are a man's best buddies, no?

There's Something About The Farrellys. You may find their brand of humour, which they patented in their hit film, There's Something About Mary, outrageous and sometimes crude. But you do get your paisa vasool laughs. So who's complaining!

The lewdness is there, with lots of wild, crazy sex and sexual banter. But there's the romance too, as Ben Stiller looks for his soul mate. He thinks he's found one in Viola, the environment volunteer who cleans up the oceans for nothing. An instant romance leads to an instant marriage, followed by an instant honeymoon and an instant break-up. Because Ben finds his real mate (Michelle) in Mexico, during his honeymoon while his wife is recovering from an acute case of sunburn. So how does he extricate himself from a bad marriage with a genteel woman who turns into a sex fiend in the bedroom? And how does he bond again with the woman of his dreams who wouldn't have anything to do with him after she realises he's two-timing?

Funny in places, randy in others, crazy all the way, this one is for those with a crooked-wicked sense of humour.

New York's tale of woe goes on and on. This time, the world's most talked about city hits the headlines when a deadly virus wipes out the entire population, leaving just two survivors: Will Smith and his dog Samantha. Well, it's two normal, recognisable survivors, because the city does have many more creatures and beasts....These are the rest of the humans who have mutated into flesh-eating vampires that hunt in packs when night falls. End result? You get one of the most outlandish scenes where lions hunt deers at Times Square and human beasts slip in and out of Central Park, in search of their khana-khazana.

movie

Hitman is one more game from Playstation to find its way on to the big screen. And like the rest of the kick butt series, this too ends up minus all thrills in its bigger avatar.

The robotic assassin, with a bar code on his bald head, is the quintessential killer who pulls the trigger bereft of all conscience-calls. But only until he meets a mysterious Russian prostitute who tries to make love to him and unleashes a whole new series of humanoid tendencies, which include ethical concerns too. The Hitman packs her in the boot of his car and sets out on a whole new journey.

movie

The ancient English epic poem about a hero comes to life in a state-of-the-art film which is absolutely new, novel and different in terms of technique. Shot in motion capture technology, the film lends a whole new meaning to computer animation, where the characters are supra-human and heroism finds a whole new metaphor, reminiscent of the earlier action fest 300.

There’s another - and more potent reason - to go wow about this new form of motion pix. It gives you Angelina Jolie in all her splendour, like never before, with a body that shimmers in the buff, a golden plait that seems to coil the entire universe in its binds and a dialect that is even more sexy than her pout. Watch her rule the world with seductive glee and get your paisa vasool moments.

For the action buffs too, there is graphic violence in a gilt-edged frame where heads are chewed off, arms torn apart and hearts yanked out without a false note or a fissure on the bow. Ekdum gory stuff. And for the acting-mangta buff, there is Anthony Hopkins lending a grandeur to the grotesque monarch, like never before.

Of course, there is the hero too, Beowulf (Winstone), the roving monster-slayer who helps King Hrothgar (Hopkins) rid his kingdom of the monster Grendel (really monstrous) only to finds himself indulging in a Faustian bargain with the monster’s yummy mummy (Jolie). This is a bargain which begets one more monster, while the ancient kingdom looks for salvation, once again.

Topicality mangta? Nations create their own monsters and then spend years trying to smoke ‘em out of caves and mountains...Go watch a new step in 70-mm masala.

Our Hollywood export returns with his second Hollywood venture, Elizabeth, ek bar phir. This time, he picks up the strings of history, thirty years after where he left off in Elizabeth l. It’s the sixteenth century again, ornate and full of intrigue.

But unlike the first film, this one is laboured and has nothing new to offer, other than a power-packed performance by Cate Blanchett who plays the eponymous role with gusto and verve. She is both vulnerable and invincible, powerful and pitiable, alpha-woman and child-woman...all at the same time.

And it is her fiery rendition of the troubled monarch that makes this tryst with history watchable, even though it does seem remote when the tempestuous present has so many stories to tell and retell. And Shekhar threatens to never say never. He threatens to come up with a third sequel to the Eliz-Ah-beth saga!

It’s familiar terrain once again. Like all royalty rigmaroles, this one too finds its drama in intrigue and romance. On the one hand, you have the aging queen flaunting her virginity in court, as she flips through suitors.

On the other, she finds her cowering under its burden, as love beckons when she meets the dashing American adventurer Walter Raleigh (Owen Wilson) who comes from the new world with a new promise of forgotten passions. But all she can get is a stolen kiss by the fireplace, while Raleigh finds a bedmate in Bess, the pretty lady-in-waiting.

And for the testosterone, there is the evil Spanish King who cuts down all the forests of Spain to built his Armada which sails towards England for war. As also, the treacherous Mary Stuart, who plots Elizabeth’s death, to bring back Catholic rule to England.

Hollywood picks up a real life story and turns into a thriller that scores not so much in its script as much as in its performance. Chris Cooper sculpts a riveting portrayal of Robert Hanssen, the senior intelligence officer who works as a Soviet spy and was convicted of treason. Currently he is serving his life sentence in solitary confinement, after he was trapped by young rookie Eric O'Neill (Ryan Phillippe) who masqueraded as his clerk in order to expose him.

The grandeur of Cooper's histrionics transform the spy into a towering figure, a man who loved his family, went to church every Sunday and managed to evoke admiration and respect from his young assistant, despite his brusque demeanour and suspect loyalties. So where are the chinks in the armour? Under the guise of a diligent intel officer, Cooper has been selling invaluable military secrets to the Soviets, although he pleads for forgiveness during confession. Having being side-stepped all his life, he nurtures a permanent grudge against the US government, because he believes that even if he continues giving his best for a hundred years, he will always remain an afterthought. It takes all of Neill's expertise to sneak through his computer files and collect incriminating evidence, without arousing his smart senior's suspicion.

Quite a riveting cat and mouse drama, reminiscent of The Departed. Of course, minus Scorcese's spellbinding touch.

A mighty topical film, that's mighty engrossing too, Winterbottom's take on the Daniel Pearl murder is an edge of the seat thriller that hits hard, and touches your heart. The story is familiar and part of post 9/11 headlines. Based on the book by Mariane Pearl, the widow of Wall Street journalist Daniel Pearl, the film follows the kidnapping, the hunt and the aftermath of Pearl's murder by Pakistani jehadis.

A five-month pregnant Marianne waits for her husband to return after an undisclosed assignment in Karachi. And when he doesn't, she sets about trying to hunt for him in a city that is chaotic and spilling over with rebels and fundamentalists. Of course, she has the FBI to help her, but she also has our very own Irrfan Khan who plays a Pakistani intelligence officer with usual competence. No where does the film get maudlin and overtly sentimental and never loses the voice of sanity, despite the sensitive issue and the expedient times.

In the end, what remains after a futile search is Marianne's million dollar message: the terrorists’ purpose was to scare us, but we are not scared. Go for the topicality of the film, the balanced tenor and the Oscar-worthy performance by Jolie.

A contract killer (Morgan Freeman), a father (John Cussack) and a son accidentally end up going on a hike together in the forests of Washington state. The killer has to be handed over to the cops and Cussack must do everything to protect his young son, even as he tries to re-build the dysfunctional relationship between them. Add the FBI, an assassination bid and a bunch of diehard killers to the track and you have a timepass thriller before you.

Of course, the film should have actually been quite average, if it wasn't for Morgan Freeman who adds gravitas to whatever he does. Even if it means playing a hitman who defines his job as 'an exterminator who removes obstacles to progress.' It's the unusual bonding between the killer and the father-son duo that lends a dignity to the proceedings. Go for Morgan alone.

Renegrade agent Jason Bourne's saga seems to be getting better and better. Not only is he impossible to kill, even though the entire might of the American secret police is gunning for him, he is also an unconventional brat, fighting them in their own lair.

This time, in his search for himself, he lands up in the heart of the CIA headquarters and discovers that he, like all the other agents, has been ruthlessly transformed in a cold killing machine from a normal human being.

movie

Batman, Superman, take a backseat. Mercury Man is here. But what’s this? The Thai superhero is hardly a match to Hollywood’s homegrown hunks, even though, like them, he seems to be blessed with some kind of kinetic superpowers that have him leapfrogging through space with a series of gravity-defying stunts. And like them, he must fight against a bad guy names Osama who dares to carry out a terrorist plot against America, with a bit of badmashi in Bangkok too.

The problem with Mercury Man is not in his conception. On the contrary it was quite a brave idea from the Thai film industry to dream of creating an indigenous superman. Mercury Man is actually a firefighter who gets injured while dousing a fire in a Bangkok prison. Stabbed by a special knife, he gets transformed into a super-kinetic man machine that takes on a terrorist who tries to destroy a Middle East-bound US ship anchored in Thai waters. The hitch lies in the execution of the pyrotechnics which are rough, jagged and quite-quite amateur.

Now why can’t the East stick to its own brand of cinema instead of churning out B-grade Hollywood clones.

There's one big reason why you should watch this film; only one. And that's the fact that we have an Indian playing the heroine to an all-American hero. Yes, Chris is the visually challenged virgin who falls in love with Anjali, the petite little receptionist (also a virgin) in his doctor's clinic. But problems begin when Anjali confesses she's Indian; which means, she's different; which means she must marry an Indian chauvinist: which means she must settle down and have babies; which means she can't go to medical school and follow her dreams....Phew!

It's a soppy little tale of cross-cultural romance that sometimes falls into familiar cliches. Like, when the American family thinks the gals wearing a curtain (oops, that's a sari buddy). But all in all, it's sugary and candy-flossy. Brave little Anjali! So what if we've never heard of you before.

Watch this film to see how far freedom of expression can actually go. If Michael Moore merely questioned Bush's policies, director Gabriel Range goes so far as to have him assassinated in this award-winning 'Fake-umentary' (The film won the critic's award at the Toronto festival recently). It's October 19, 2007 when Bush falls to an assassin's bullets in the streets of Chicago as his motorcade is trapped in the midst of stringent anti-Bush protests. You can actually see Bush crumbling (how did they do it?) and later witness his funeral procession (that's ostensibly footage from Reagan's funeral procession), even as President Dick Cheney hails him as a gracious and gallant man in his farewell address.

But that's the hypothetical premise of the film which is actually an investigation of America under Bush. While the government immediately finds the killer who fits the perfect racial profile, a Syrian who had attended an Al-Qaida camp in Pakistan, the assassin actually turns out to be a native American who loved his country, ''but loved God and his sons even more''. The ex-Gulf war veteran had lost two sons in Iraq — one died and the other returned a wreck — and realised that it was not right to die for 'lies' and an 'immoral cause.' Does the American government reveal the true identity of the killer or does it's racial profiling continue? That's the provocative indictment the film makes as it jiggles it's pro-Bush and anti-Bush protagonists.

The film follows the format of a documentary with most of the shots taken by hand-held cameras. But that doesn't diminish the power of its incisive critique of post 9/11 America. Imagine, if an Indian filmmaker tried to make this kind of a film about a living Indian politician? Hara kiri, indeed!

They call him the priest from hell, because he puts all young couples through a gruelling pre-nuptial test before blessing them with the wedding vows. This time his victims are Mandy Moore and John Krasinki who decide to undergo the ordeal which includes all kinds of oddities lke bedroom surveillance and bringing up fake babies.

Do the youngsters flunk the test? No one’s interested ‘cause the film has nothing to offer. It's neither comic nor serious. Even Robin Williams fails to find his bearings as Reverend Frank, the sadistic priest who has his own weird theories of love and marriage.

It's a modern day Midsummer Night's Dream set in sylvan Oregon where Morgan Freeman plays head priest in this delectable feast of amorous bits and bites.
The film follows a pattern similar to Salaam-e-Ishq, where different couples play out a varied montage of love. Leading the pack is Freeman, a wise professor who tries to cope with the untimely death of his son and finds a soul mate in his companion for life, his wife.

Then, you have broken-hearted Kinnear who tries to begin anew (with Radha Mitchell), after his wife runs away for a lesbian relationship. And you have Radha Mitchell who must decide whether her dream man is the simple coffee-shop owner (Kinnear) or the married man she's been dating...

Sugary sweet vignettes of love are strung together and laid out in a feast that's spartan rather than sumptuous. The pace is languorous and the drama laid back. But the warmth is truly infectious.

What's happening to me? yells Potter, sending the avuncular Dumbledore and his faithful friends, Ron and Hermione into a tizzy. Why am I always angry? I feel I'm turning BAD!, he exclaims, setting the undertone for his fifth year at Hogwarts. Ever since his encounter with Voldermort in the last film, The Goblet of Fire, life has never been the same for the boy wizard. He not only lost his friend in the last episode, but also his boyishness. Welcome to Harry, the harried teen, who knows it's not going to be easy any more. No more quidditch, no more carefree wanderings with Hagrid, no bindaas buddy business with Ron and Hermione and no private concerns of problems at Privet Drive. Family problems are hardly the concern now when the entire wizard world is threatened by You Know Who and his horrid army. Harry knows his destiny: it's either him or Voldermort in the epic battle of good against evil, and he doesn't need the prophecy to tell him so...

movie

And we thought fairy tales were meant for little kids! Here’s a quixotic pariyon ki kahani for adults, laced with delicious fantasy, dreamy landscapes and an allegorical tenor that makes Stardust a watchable parable on love and life in materialistic times.

Young Tristian (Charlie Cox) loves sassy Victoria (Sienna Miller) who is an inveterate tease. She wants her boyfriend to bring her a fallen star, before she reciprocates and the ardent lover sets out in search of taare zameen par. Of course he finds one, only it happens to be a glowing gal (Claire Danes) who has her own theories about unconditional, uncontrollable, unbounded love. It doesn’t take long for the boy to transfer his emotions, but love is truly star-crossed. Specially since, there are so many people in search of a fallen star. Most importantly, there’s the menacing witch (Michelle Pfieffer) who wants the star’s heart to find the formula of eternal youth. And a crooked pirate (Robert DeNiro) who wants to play big daddy to the ill-fated duo.

Got the point? With witches, pirates, ghosts and celestial beings, the stage is set for some Lord of the Rings — Tales from Narnia kind of special effects. The main architect being manic Michelle who is in perfect Catwoman form. She uses her finger to chop heads in a classic game of heads or tales and doesn’t forget to look into the mirror and sigh at her greying hair. Not to be left behind is the second heavyweight performer, DeNiro who plays Captain Shakespeare with paternal glee, but only when he’s not wearing petticoats and dancing the cancan in privacy.

Catch the madness, even if you can’t catch a falling star.

An American actress comes to India to try her luck in the ‘musicals’, a euphemism for Bollywood films. She meets the perfect Indian male, her choreographer, Salman Khan and naturally falls in love with him when she discovers he’s the proverbial prince too. My Prince! she exhorts and almost swoons in his palace in Jodhpur. But fairy tales always don’t come true and the lovers realise that tradition is traditionally more exalted than love in the Indian scheme of things. So it’s back to Barry the boyfriend for the American starlet, Marigold while the Indian prince kowtows to his family’s commands and decides to settle for the traditional Indian miss (Nandana Dev Sen). But hey! what’s this? The Indian lass prefers to smoke secretly in the haveli’s backyard, baring her heart to the cuckolded gora, even as the gori dons the henna, the lehnga and the sequinned choli....

movie

Here's one more film straight out of the current turmoil. Would the world have no Iraq, Afghanistan, Al-Qaida, Taliban and the West, if there was no other? Would there be no clash of civilisations, no war against terror, no terrorists and no victims, if humans were no longer humans, just human-like minus all emotions?

That's the thought-provoking premise behind Invasion. But the conclusion — there gotta be differences and hence war as long as we are humans — is definitely disconcerting. As is the sleepy tenor of the film and the sorry second coming of our new Bond (Daniel Craig) in a thakela new avtaar. He's psychiatrist Nicole Kidman's love interest and soldier-in-arms as she battles an invasion of an alien virus that lands on earth after a space shuttle crash lands on earth. The virus is gradually infecting the entire city and transforming the inhabitants into unfeeling robots and the only antidote is a state of sleeplessness. Or else, Kidman's little kid who is the only immune fella. Kidman needs to stay awake and save her kid, along with the entire human race. Indeed, a tough task for our overburdened supergirl!

Kidman and Craig fail to crackle together and the film simply slumbers on after a point.

Finally, 9/11 too has become a formula for Hollywood to build its stories on. Lions for Lambs, Redacted, Valley of Elah, Rendition and The Kingdom are films which center their action in and around the politics of jehad and the war against terror. But some of the films get introspective, some raise questions and some just use the exotic backdrop for run-of-the-mill action. The Kingdom sadly falls in the last category where suicide bombers and Arab terrorists are sprinkled in typical FBI smoke 'em out drama.

Things are going fine in the America's oil kingdom (Saudi Arabia), until a blast occurs in an American compound, killing innocent families who were spending their ‘chutti' playing baseball. The FBI sends a crack team -- Jamie Foxx, Chris Cooper, Jennifer Garner -- to Riyadh to catch the terrorists, which they do after a long and bloody chase which sees some more bombs being crafted and exploded.

There's nothing new to keep you glued, despite the fact that Jamie Foxx and Chris Cooper are amongst the diehard dependables of Hollywood. Blame it on the unimaginative script, ek baar phir.

Is this still America, asks a teenage sex worker, as she lies mauled and beaten up by a customer. Time for Jodie Foster to play victim once more. But this time, she picks up the gun and dons the mantle of the vigilante who must clean-up crime-infested New York city, after she loses her boyfriend (Naveen Andrews) in a mindless subway shootout.

Her first act of violence is in self-defence, as she tries to protect herself from a pair of thugs in the metro, but soon it becomes a mission. She prowls the suburban underbelly and ferrets out the scum, because, as she insists, the American soul is essentially horrid and a murderer. Tch Tch! Ask Iraq, Afghanistan. Foster is still a fistful of power. And why not. 'Coz wasn't she the one who got Hannibal Lecter first.

Truly, a duh-nut of a film, this one is meant to make you sit back and have fun while America's No.l dysfunctional family sets the world in disorder.

Homer Simpson pollutes the lake with pig crap and has the US government gunning not only for him but for the whole town. The slyvan township of nerds, drop-outs and care-free bums might soon turn into a new Grand Canyon, after being domed out of the US map, unless Homer decides to do something for his 'dome' (read dumb) people. But Homer's escaped to the exotic Arctic and is busy with the birds, bees and bambis. And it will take more than wife Marge and son Bart's bickerings to tickle his voice of conscience. It will take loads of Innuit mumbo-jumbo to bring out the MAN from the muddle. But once risen, Homer is truly 'duh' hero of the day.

A great dig at all that's American, including President Shwarzenneger who says he's been elected to lead not read (remember Bush reading My Pet Goat upside down, while the WTC fell), The Simpsons Movie is quite mazedar.

Hollywood, you aren't alone now. Korea begins its film exports to India and has a long list in the pipeline. But surely, The Host wasn't the perfect film to begin with. Not when Hollywood has perfected the art of Jurassic Park. Why would anybody want to watch a country cousin of the hi-tech dinos of Spielberg's super thriller?

The film captures the exploits of a young girl who tries to escape the fangs of a weird monster that inhabits the sewers of the city. The monster, a mix between Godzilla and T-Rex loves to keep its larder full of rotting humans and gorges on them after spitting out all the useless skulls, bones and coke cans that have bloated its belly. And it takes more than human ingenuity to capture the leaping, chomping killing machine. It takes two long and listless hours of watching the same thing over and again....

Korean cinema, like Chinese cinema, has created a niche for itself in the festival circuit. Now can't we have imports that are quintessentially Korean rather than pale copies of Hollywood.

Norman Bates returns in a nondescript manner. No, this isn't Psycho 2, but the director does seem to be heavily inspired by the Hitchcock classic. Of course, his motel can hardly live up to the reputation of the infamous Bates Motel, even though the owner tries his best to keep up the creepy work. He not only has his inmates killed by a bunch of in-house killers, but he uses hidden cameras to make snuff films which bring in rich dividends.

This time, his victims are a bickering couple (Beckinsale and Wilson) who end up for a night at the eerie motel. But they soon realise that cockroaches in bed are hardly the problem. Hanging on to dear life is the bigger and more important one. Somebody's banging on their door, masked killers are silhouetted against their window and the bathroom has bloodied apples thrown into it. Their only escape seems to be a rat-infested tunnel but that too has a dead end. So what do our victims too? Creep, crawl, cry and wait for the dawn to break and end the nightmare...

We wait too, because like most of its current crop of horror films, this slasher film too is C-grade Hollywood. Now what's this Ms Beckinsale?

Watch this one only because you’ll never get to see this kind of cinema in India. Can an Indian filmmaker ever dare to make an irreverent film on a leading public figure and get away with it? Nah! the film will be immediately banned. But Frears not only makes film on the monarchy and shows them up as ‘insensitive’ and ‘outdated’, he even wins an Oscar for it (Best screenplay and Best Actress for Helen Mirren). At one point, you even have Cherie Blair branding the British Royals as ‘emotionally retarded freeloaders’. Now, now, anybody allowed to speak out like this here?

movie

Vampires take over a small town in Alaska after the sun sets on the last day, unleashing 30 night-filled days when daylight becomes a thing of the past. People are gored to death and blood fills the darkened streets, while the town waits for succour. And we wait for daylight...

Now if Hollywood wants to make another vampire film, it needs to add something new. No more of those bloody fangs on those ashen faces, please. And no, not Josh Hartnett as a vampire slayer. The boy's too sweet to swim through the bloodfest, even though he's got Melissa George (his ex-wife in the film) to keep him company. Poor girl, she missed the last flight out of town and ended up fighting for life in a supermarket infested with blood thirsty beasts.

Guess we've got better things to do with our days and nights.

This one is Pulp Fiction revisited. Michael Davis is a self-confessed Quentin Tarantino and John Woo fan and pays homage to their cinema of the fast cut, the violence playfest and the funky, overdone frames which look as if they have pulled out of a museum of post-modern art.

Anonymous, anyman Mr Smith (delightfully deadpan Owen) listlessly sits and eats a carrot on a bus stop when he sees an assassin chasing a pregnant woman. Carrot in hand, he tries to save the woman, delivers her baby in the bonnet of the car and thinks he has shot the killer.

But the killer (Giamatti) keeps brushing off the bullets and never gives up the chase, while Owen tries to protect the baby and its wet nurse (yes, it's garam masala Monica Bellucci) who is actually a kind-hearted prostitute....Irrelevant, all this story.

What matters are the action cuts — and there are loads of them — which have you witness some wacko gun wizardry, as bullets fly during a love-making scene too. Ekdum Hardboiled, like Woo. With a bit about family and love.

The Indian diaspora finally finds its voice: elegant, articulate and ekdum real. Here, there is no hysterical clash-of-culture cacophony about how the Patels, Gangulis and the Punjabis leave India, only to create Little India’s all over the world. And here there is no hullabaloo about the Angrezi-born-confused-desi dilemmas that the second generation NRI kids succumb to: an overdose of drugs, sex and the dark side of the moon. Instead, there is a gentle probing, a mild introspection on cross cultural conflicts coupled with a quiet celebration of the idea of India, minus all chauvinism.

If Monsoon Wedding was a wild and rumbustious festival of India (read Punjabi culture), then The Namesake is a Haiku about Hindustan: minimalist, magical and intensely moving. Mira Nair takes Jhumpa Lahiri's novel and transforms it into visual poetics, using her colour palette to create a riveting kaleidoscope of contrasts.

movie

It’s the third in the Resident Evil franchise which is based on the popular Capcom video game series. And it is the best when compared to the earlier two, Resident Evil and Resident Evil Apocalypse.

Our heroine Alice (Milla Jovovich) returns after she had escaped from the zombie-run Racoon City, only to land up in zombie-run Las Vegas. Her destination is Alaska where she must find a safe haven from the sinister Umbrella Corporation run by the evil Dr Issacs.

Go see Jovovich run for her life, helped by a bunch of renegade buddies, led by Ali Larter (remember Marigold?). But before she can find a safe haven, she must combat all kinds of geeky creatures which include weird hounds and ravenous ravens. This actually means you can get your prescribed dose of grime and gore, which is the quintessential lure of this franchise.

For all you Milla watchers, there’s lots to watch, including a Milla in silken sheets, along with one in a cocktail dress and boots, ready to kick butt and flip bullets. And for the fun parts, there’s the kinky skeletal zombie trying to learn how to handle a cellphone and a digital camera. But that’s only when he’s not feasting himself on human flesh and gleefully wiping off the blood from his face.

Thank God for violent video games! They supposedly subsume all our violent tendencies and make us genteel souls, don’t they?

The motormouth (Tucker) and the hit machine (Chan) are back. But they have nothing new to offer in their gag bag. However, don't worry, the film tickles you in places, specially when the French cabbie man longs to be an American by doing what the Americans do: killing people for no reason at all!

movie

Ready for one more penguin movie after Happy Feet and March of the Penguins? Now who can explain Hollywood's current obsession with this species. Soon they'll be saying penguins were the ancestors of man!

Anyways, here there's a penguin who wants to win a surfing competition and knows he can only win the Shiverpool league if he takes some tuition and training from Z (Jeff Bridges), his idol and now, mentor. Loads of low brow humor and some great animation, nevertheless, deja vu remains.

A super-natural thriller, the film could have been a Sixth Sense or a Memento.

It isn’t. Instead, it ends up as rather drab, with Sandra Bullock playing a listless housewife who gets the days of the week mixed up and sees her husband dead one day, only to find him alive the next.

It’s up to the devoted wife to work on her premonitions and prevent her husband’s death, so what if she discovers he’s been two-timing her as well. She’s the good wife...sadly all goody-goody stuff ends up as slush.

Hitchcock revisited

Disturbia is actually a teen flick that brings back memories of Rear Window. Of course, the film is hardly a classic like the cult film, but it does keep you riveted as you join young Shia LeBeouf’s voyeuristic adventures that find him chasing a killer from his bedroom window. Kewl stuff!

Shia loses his dad in a car accident and ends up a disturbed teen who can’t forget the horror. He pounds up his teacher in class and ends up under house arrest for three months with nothing but his laptop, his TV and his video games to keep him company.

Of course he’s got yummy mummy, the Matrix girl, Carrie-Ann playing mom, but he doesn’t seem to really care. Bored of all the usual stuff, he takes to snooping on his neighbours through a pair of binoculars, which after lingering on bikinis and porn TV, ends up panning on the shady neighbour who loves to mow his lawn and snoop around at midnight. Soon, he begins to see body parts too and is called upon to play neighbourhood vigilante.

Disturbia keeps the popcorn cracking.

Three villains, a doubting girlfriend, a hard-to-resist seductress and some evil alien goop: Spider-Man has too many troubles to let him free fly and free fall in this prolonged (139 minutes), pricey third instalment.

Spidey 3, they say is the most expensive film of the trilogy, but does it give you more bang for the bigger buck? Poor guy, he's hardly the Superhero he used to be. And he's even made to confess that he can't battle all the bad guys alone.

Will one of the bad guys (old friend Harry, now the Green Goblin) turn good and help Spidey save the world from this multi-pronged evil? And believe it or not, the Green Goblin ends up even more endearing than our webbed wonder, with more people — including Spidey and Mary Jane — shedding tears on his save-Spidey mission.

movie

Call it reversal of roles, but this is the film which was released last week in the US along with Saawariya and Om Shanti Om and, according to the Hollywood Reporter, it lost out to both of them at the box office. This, despite the fact that the film has a premier cast and a hot topic. It castigates America's war against terror, with Tom Cruise playing a Bush-like senator who can't see beyond getting into (read, hanging on to) the White House, even if it means bungling up drastically in Iraq, Afghanistan and God knows where else...Has Bollywood grown bigger (globally speaking) than Hollywood! The film moves at three basic levels.

First, there is the skeptical journalist (Streep) who interviews the senator on the government's blundering foreign policy. And even as the senator boasts about embarking upon a new, error-proof strategy in the war against terror, you have sequence two, where young American soldiers fight for survival in hostile, jehadi terrain. And finally, there is the third sequence where a weary professor (Robert Redford) tries to infuse a new vigour in his apathetic young students who believe Standford and Harvard are the only way to fulfil the American dream. No! roars the prof. Rome is burning and you got to douse the flames; stand up and protest, he exhorts in Bob Marley baritone. The scene stealer is Tom Cruise of course who is a pucca Bush clone, complete with the bull-headed blindness towards reason and logic. He shows what realpolitik is all about, as he hardsells a useless, gone-awry war as essential and inevitable; America's only ticket to super cop status.

Streep articulates the misgivings of the common American, while Redford raises the long-forgotten banner of protest amidst a conformist polity. It's a sensible voice, but a verbose voice. There is too much of talking, when cinema isn't about words alone. The film is essentially one long conversation, divided into three sequences. Nevertheless, you listen because it is a topical and sensible diatribe against post 9/11 America.

He's a smalltime magician who has a special gift. He can look into the future -- two minutes, before an event actually transpires -- and sometimes even change it. But more importantly, he's Nicholas Cage, an actor who can make a sleepwalker's film worth a dekko.

Cage tries to hide his gift by leading a non-descript life in the backwaters of Colorado. But the FBI (Julliane Moore) seeks him out and solicits his help to find a secret bomb that has been hidden somewhere by a bunch of mercenaries.

Cage doesn't want to get embroiled in national issues, especially when he can spend his nights and days with golden tanned go-go gal (Jessica Biel) in the golden rocks of the Grand Canyon. Alas! When country calls, there can be no resisting, specially in a post 9/11 clime.

Hence, it's time to duck bullets and dodge canons, as clairvoyant Cage tries to save the nation and his nymph. Interesting.

If only life were as simple as a recipe, sighs super chef Catherine Zeta Zones as things go helter-skelter in her ordered life, once she begins to open up her heart. First to her young niece (Little Miss Sunshine, Abigail Breslin) after she is orphaned and moves in with all her little fears.

And then, to her rival, the savvy new sous-chef (Aaron Eckhart) who threatens to take over her kitchen with his finger-smacking recipes and his dashing charisma that unfolds while he cooks with Pavorrati playing on full volume.

So what's a power woman all about? Cold and unfeeling, wedded only to her career or can she be the gentle mother and giving wife too? That's the conundrum which this affable film tries to unspool as it whips up a smooth and creamy romance between the super-chef and her assistant in the kitchen of an upmarket New York restaurant. Lesson to be learnt? There can be no reservations between loved ones and the best recipes in life are the one’s that each one makes up for himself/herself.

Watch out for the heart tugging sequences between the little miss Abigail and Zeta-Jones who graduates from imperfect mother to perfect guardian. And linger on the succulent candle-lit dinners between the two chefs.

Overbearing, interfering, meddlesome moms...now that's a fondly irritating reality most people have gone through. As is Because I said so, a statement that has been part and parcel of most dads' and moms' disciplinings. The film pays tribute to this all-pervasive experience as it captures the dogged attempts of Diane Keaton who tries to 'direct' daughter Mandy Moore's life and love affairs, even when she's clearly redundant. But as Diane piteously asks: When does a mom know when it's time to stop playing mom?!

Never! The funny parts are laidback, the romantic bits hardly sizzle and the acting isn't much to write about, yet the film strikes a chord because the story is so familiar. Of course, Diane tries her best to sparkle as the mom who sets up her daughter with the ideal match which she finds on the internet. Only, the daughter has a penchant for falling for all the wrong types, this time for a single dad with a spunky son. So who will it be? Rich guy with the family heirlooms or rough-and-tumble guy with the easy attitude? No prizes for guessing. Haven't we seen enough of fairy tales unfold on silver screens...

Is he the same guy who gave us LA Confidential? Well, Curtis Hanson seems to be completely out of form in this washed out romance between a poker player (Bana) and a lounge singer (Barrymore).

Bana tries to make it big in the world of poker, even as Barrymore hopes to get a break as a pop crooner. And somewhere between chasing their ambitions, they fall in love. Sadly, the love story too unfolds in the poker room and lacks all fire. All in all, this one's truly a poker-faced drama.

Thomas Harris continues delving into the psyche of pop culture’s favourite cannibal who rewrote the rules of cannibalism with The Silence of the Lambs. This time, the writer delves into Hannibal Lecter’s tortured past to tell us why his favourite cuisine is fava beans, Chianti and human cheeks.

Blame it on the bad Nazis who not only gassed innocent people, but ate some of the kids too. Back to 1944, Lithuania, when Hannibal was just a little boy, a bunch of starving thugs boiled his kid sister and managed to survive the war. Hannibal, who witnessed this horrific feast, naturally ended up messed up for life. The only way to end his nightmares was to find his sister’s killers and chew their cheeks off. So what if it means losing the only woman he loved, a delectable Japanese aunt (Gong Li) who sent him to medical school and tried to smoothen out his soul.

It may not be as rivetting as The Silence of the Lambs, but Hannibal Rising is gritty a fare nonetheless with French heartthrob, Gaspard Ulliel giving a fitting lean-mean beginning to Anthony Hopkins flashy sophistication in the other two films. More importantly, the violence is suggestive although the terror is never understated. In the end, you are told the cheek-chewer was just a wronged soul in search of vengeance against a world that ate his chubby sister. Indeed, a strange new world in cinema!

It's Aishwarya's film from the word go.

From the very first shot, the actor grabs the role by its horns and shakes it around to sculpt a moving portrayal of a battered woman who happens to chance upon a rare source of inner strength to fight against domestic terror and terrifying traditions that demand silence from a wife, come what may.

Based on the true story of Kiranjit Ahluwalia, who managed to find freedom, dignity and a life of her own after ending ten years of marital abuse with the drastic act of murdering her sleeping husband, Provoked draws its strength from two sources.

movie

The superheroes are back and what a homecoming! In a post 9/11 world, when all our superheroes — Batman, Superman, Spiderman — are becoming philosophical, introspective and moody about their magical powers, the Fantastic Four are still fun-loving and untroubled by existential woes.

Thank God for that! To be or not to be: no Hamletian dilemmas for this foursome that knows it has to save the world from the inimical Dr Doom with its special powers of stretchy limbs (Reed), electrical force fields (Storm), human torch infernos (Johnny) or just sheer power (Ben). And no cerebral debates on good versus evil or the evil within in this high octane drama, laced with state-of-the-art special effects. Enough to give the kid in you chills, thrills and marvels.

movie
